module.name: mouse
module.descr: The Mouse unit implements a platform independent mouse handling interface. It is implemented identically on all platforms supported by Free Pascal and can be enhanced with custom drivers, should this be needed. It is intended to be used only in text-based screens, for instance in conjunction with the keyboard and video unit. No support for graphical screens is implemented, and there are (currently) no plans to implement this.

element.name: MouseEventBufSize
element.descr: The mouse unit has a mechanism to buffer mouse events. This constant defines the size of the event buffer.

descr.p: The TMouseEvent is the central type of the mouse unit, it is used to describe all mouse events.

The Buttons field describes which buttons were down when the event occurred. The x,y fields describe where the event occurred on the screen. The Action describes what action was going on when the event occurred. The Buttons and Action field can be examined using the constants defined in the unit interface.

element.name: TMouseEvent.Buttons
element.short: Pressed buttons at time of event.

element.name: TMouseDriver
element.descr: The TMouseDriver record is used to implement a mouse driver in the function. Its fields must be filled in before calling the function.

element.name: TMouseDriver.UseDefaultQueue
element.short: Should the default event queue mechanism be used.

element.name: TMouseDriver.DoneDriver

element.name: TMouseDriver.GetMouseY
element.short: Called to get the mouse cursors vertical position.

element.name: TMouseDriver.GetMouseButtons
element.short: Called to get the currently pressed mouse buttons.

element.name: TMouseDriver.SetMouseXY
element.short: Called when the current mouse position must be set.

element.name: MouseIntFlag
element.descr: This variable keeps track of the last known internal mouse state. Do not use.

element.name: MouseButtons
element.descr: This variable keeps track of the last known mouse button state. Do not use.

element.name: MouseWhereX
element.descr: This variable keeps track of the last known cursor position. Do not use.

element.name: MouseWhereY
element.descr: This variable keeps track of the last known cursor position. Do not use.

element.name: DetectMouse
element.short: Detect the presence of a mouse.

descr.p: DetectMouse detects whether a mouse is attached to the system or not. If there is no mouse, then zero is returned. If a mouse is attached, then the number of mouse buttons is returnead.
This function should be called after the mouse driver was initialized.

DoneMouse De-initializes the mouse driver. It cleans up any memory allocated when the mouse was initialized, or removes possible mouse hooks from memory. The mouse functions will not work after DoneMouse was called. If DoneMouse is called a second time, it will exit at once. InitMouse should be called before DoneMouse can be called again.
For an example, see most other mouse functions.

element.name: GetMouseButtons
element.short: Get the state of the mouse buttons

descr.p: GetMouseButtons returns the current button state of the mouse, i.e. it returns a or-ed combination of the following constants:

dl.dd: When the left mouse button is held down.
When the right mouse button is held down.
When the middle mouse button is held down.

element.name: GetMouseDriver
element.short: Get a copy of the currently active mouse driver.

descr.p: GetMouseDriver returns the currently set mouse driver. It can be used to retrieve the current mouse driver, and override certain callbacks.
A more detailed explanation about getting and setting mouse drivers can be found in .
For an example, see the section on writing a custom mouse driver,

element.name: GetMouseEvent
element.short: Get next mouse event from the queue.

descr.p: GetMouseEvent returns the next mouse event (a movement, button press or button release), and waits for one if none is available in the queue.
Some mouse drivers can implement a mouse event queue which can hold multiple events till they are fetched. Others don't, and in that case, a one-event queue is implemented for use with .

element.name: GetMouseX
element.short: Query the current horizontal position of the mouse cursor.
element.descr: GetMouseX returns the current X position of the mouse. X is measured in characters, starting at 0 for the left side of the screen.

element.name: GetMouseY
element.short: Query the current vertical position of the mouse cursor.

descr.p: GetMouseY returns the current Y position of the mouse. Y is measured in characters, starting at 0 for the top of the screen.
For an example, see

element.name: HideMouse
element.descr: HideMouse hides the mouse cursor. This may or may not be implemented on all systems, and depends on the driver.

descr.p: InitMouse Initializes the mouse driver. This will allocate any data structures needed for the mouse to function. All mouse functions can be used after a call to InitMouse.
A call to InitMouse must always be followed by a call to at program exit. Failing to do so may leave the mouse in an unusable state, or may result in memory leaks.
For an example, see most other functions.

element.name: PollMouseEvent
element.short: Query next mouse event. Do not wait if none available.

descr.p: PollMouseEvent checks whether a mouse event is available, and returns it in MouseEvent if one is found. The function result is True in that case. If no mouse event is pending, the function result is False, and the contents of MouseEvent is undefined.
Note that after a call to PollMouseEvent, the event should still be removed from the mouse event queue with a call to GetMouseEvent.

element.name: PutMouseEvent
element.short: Put a mouse event in the venet queue.

descr.p: PutMouseEvent adds MouseEvent to the input queue. The next call to or PollMouseEvent will then return MouseEvent.
Please note that depending on the implementation the mouse event queue can hold only one value.

element.name: SetMouseXY
element.descr: SetMouseXY places the mouse cursor on X,Y. X and Y are zero based character coordinates: 0,0 is the top-left corner of the screen, and the position is in character cells (i.e. not in pixels).

The mouse unit has support for adding a custom mouse driver. This can be used to add support for mouses not supported by the standard Free Pascal driver, but also to enhance an existing driver for instance to log mouse events or to implement a record and playback function.
